data.text: Packable Cooking Gear: JetBoil, Primus, etc?

Cooking stuff‚Ä¶ What to choose. Been looking at jet boil and primus. I need something that doesn‚Äôt take much space. Packs easy in ‚Äùitself‚Äù, like jet boil. Being able to cook normal food, aka scrambled egg on a beef. Hard to do on the cup designed boilers. Help‚Ä¶
MSR served us well.
data.author: Grant Griffin

data.text: Cooker of your choice and a titanium frypan. Personally, i would go for a cooker with a bigger burner if you want to do steaks etc. The jetboil types are only really good for boiling as, the flame is too concentrated for a proper cook.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I really liked MSR and dome other white gas users, but Ive never found white gas in some countries and gas reeks horribly. Id suggest u ask people where u r going what is found there.
data.author: Kenny Barks

data.text: It's the pots and pans that take up space, the burner not so much. So get a versatile burner, like the Primus Gravity III for example, and choose pots according to adventure (what kind of cooking, number of people etc.)
data.author: Markus Weckman

data.text: Same as what micheal said the burners of jetboils and other types of those stoves have a too focussef flame steaks you burn in the middle while the sides arnt even cooked yet this is the reason i took a 2nd burner with me on longer trips with a bigger spread out flame to make a proper meal and if you take 2 small cans of gas anyway like i did its not that much extra weight but does give you a second burner
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Msr whisperlite. Jetboils are great for boiling water but pretty awful for cooking anything else. And the msr can run on kerosene, or even regular gasoline if need be.
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: and you don‚Äôt throw away empty fuel canisters!
data.author: Tom Possert

data.text: whisperlite all the way. There‚Äôs a reason it‚Äôs been used in this way for decades. You can simmer with it even, using a few small workarounds.
data.author: Isaac Brooks

data.text: please share your simmering secrets for whisperlight. Maybe I need a thicker pot, but I always burn when I have to cook anything longer then a few minutes unless I stand there and pick it up off the heat every few seconds.
data.author: Alison Emily Baker

data.text: Burning pump gas in Canada is strongly unrecommended due to the additives it contains. My Optimus and "Nam stove" are staying on the shelf.
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: Primus for me as it will burn any fuel type.. but more expensive, but more versatile in the long run. Especially in Europe where they don't mind you filling up your fuel bottle at the petrol stations If howeveryour touring in the uk then go for gas only like the MSR pocket rocket as getting gas is really easy.. hope this helps
data.author: Paul Wood

data.text: MSR Wisperalight definitely
data.author: Tina Brocklebank

data.text: Don't cook. Your body doesn't NEED hot food. It's just desire. Simplify your packing, and save time. You're doing a cycling tour, not staying at home. Discard expectations üéà
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: Yes, best advice!
data.author: Tom Possert

data.text: we have come to the conclusion our so called cycle tours are really just camping/picnic tours, because we get to have 3 picnics a day, all in wonderful locations. Our meals, especially our hot dinners, are usually among our highlights of the day.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: you do you. Let others do their thing. Some of us are on continuous long tours. Eating apples and other rabbit food isn't enough for months on end. A hot dinner with meat is usually the highlight of the day and doesn't happened everyday. If you're vegan, keep it to yourself. No body cares about your "religion"
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: actually, it's wine, cheese, bread and quality cold cuts. I am not frugal, just can't be bothered with the hassle of prepping, cooking and cleaning whilst I tour. As you say....
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: same. Hate clean up. Most night for me it's a block of cheese, dry salami and bread or crackers. Im in Europe now so it's easy to find foods. In central Asia it's different. Sometime all there is, is your stock piles of ramen noodles, rice, pasta
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: Don't stop to sleep, your body doesn't NEED to be horizontal. It's just desire. Save time. You're on a bicycle tour not at home. Discard expectations!
data.author: Dennis Irvine

data.text: I could tour without hot meals but couldn‚Äôt cycle a km without coffee! A coffee is a mandatory drink as soon as I wake up!
data.author: Omare War

data.text: Italy is the place for you üíö
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: Trangia, good sized pots and kettle that all pack into the stove with space for cutlery, pot lifter, salt and some tea bags.
data.author: Findlay McLaren

data.text: I was given a Trangia mini 28, by a traveller who was going home. It is great. I am using surgical alcohol from the pharmacy, and it burns cleaner than most meths. I can only get 75% abv, but it works fine, it burns a bit slower but that is better for simmering and frying eggs. In the past I had always liked the idea, but did not like the sheer size of the Trangia cooksets. They are light but, for me, took up too much space. The Trangia Mini on the other hand is tiny by comparison. I also carry a small round food box, a collapsible cup and bowl and a cutting board. All, except the cutting board, stash together, with the cup and bowl sitting on top of the rest of the cookset. Recently I have changed my setup. I kept the Mini's wind shield/pot stand and burner, but have switched out the pots to the Kovea Solo 2 pot set (minus the Kovea spoons and bowls). Including the folding the folding cup and folding bowl, it all packs down/nests into the pots, about 16.5 cm diameter by 12 cm tall. This is a comparable size to my Mini 28 kit. I changed to a two pot set as it suits how I cook better; although the Trangia mini is more than adequate. Note for Kovea Solo owners, I have just bought some silicon tubing online, to put over the handles as for some reason Kovea do not insulate them, unlike many cheaper pot sets.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Addendum, here is the modified set up I am using now. This packs down to 16.5 cm diameter by 12 cm tall.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: MSR Pocket Rocket worked well for us including a small frypan. Folds up super small yet gives out heaps of heat to cook most things and boils water super fast. (Assuming you can get a gas canister)
data.author: Diane Ridgway

data.text: I disagree about Jetboil. I was able to prepare hot food for 5 riders on 2 Jetboils ( mine and a friends old one) with minimal pots and pans. Burning in the middle is minimised by solid stirring.
data.author: Ross Mayberry

data.text: Trangia- defiantly.
data.author: Kirsten Hooge Hellum

data.text: My first stove was a fosters beer can, and the most reliable.
data.author: Paul Rodriguez

data.text: The best camping skillet, by far, that I have seen, is the Jetboil Summit skillet. I think the base has varying thickness to spread the heat more evenly, and it has a ceramic non-stick coating. Possibly perfect for steaks. There are lots of reviews for this skillet online. If you are going to go gas. I bought a spider/remote type stove and a butane cassette adapter. The stove has a bigger burner, and becuase it sits on the ground it is more stable and it is harder to topple over with a pot of food on it. With the adapter I can use regular screw fit canister (camping gaz type) gas or I can use the adapter to fuel from butane cassettes (that look more like a household aersol can) that are much cheaper. The spider stove also packs down fairly small (not as small as the jetboil types) and will nest into many small pots.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Tomshoo. Don‚Äôt forget about getting wood for higher altitudes/stormy weather.
data.author: Giulia Juh√©

data.text: Go away with it all. Enjoy green apples fruit more fruit nuts delicious pastries local food when you can and when not stock up.
data.author: Steve Hutton

data.text: Thanks guys. It is a goldmine of knowledge in here. Trangia is super simple and effective. Looks like a go‚Ä¶
data.author: Thomas Hoflund

data.text: You could try a solo stove ... a small handfull of twigs is enough for a boil ... fully contained fire ... fits inside a pot ... very lightweight ... no fuel to buy ... can house a trangia style alcohol burner for backup if needed
data.author: Stuart Mather

data.text: Have you used it for extented cooking, like one pot to boil something and then another to fry, does it perform ok?
data.author: Dennis Irvine

data.text: Aye it will plod along as long as you keep feeding it twigs ... if frying though I tend to pack the stove well with thumb sized sticks as well because the width of a frying pan can make it awkward to reach the feeding gap to trickle feed twigs ... it's still doable but I just find packing it with wood a bit easier for frying ... it's very efficient so there's not much ash to deal with as it double burns so as long as you have a little pile of fuel you can keep if going for ages .... it's also possible to handle and move the stove (carefully) even when lit as the outer skin remains relatively cool .... mine has paid for itself many times over in fuel savings
data.author: Stuart Mather

data.text: My personal experience with multi-fuel heaters is shit, others go happy fires, but they always get stuffed by unclean fuel and makes my life difficult. Clean gas is easy, but not always around. Bushcraft makes bushbox, very interesting for no gas small kitchen fires
data.author: Svend Jepsen

data.text: Mess tins
data.author: Dave Prestidge

data.text: I've been using a Trangia Mini for decades. The stove part stores inside the .75L pot, with the frying pan as the lid. I use 99% Methyl Hydrate (methyl alcohol) as fuel, as it's easy to find in Canada in 1L bottles and is safer and cleaner than the gasoline my old Optimus stove used.
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: I do all of that in my JetBoil Stash. Low heat. Cooks everything great.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: 1100ml Ti pot n pan by Toaks with a Simple stoves burner.. stove nests in the pot and it all fits in a fork park
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: You may be asking the wrong question. Do you want to simmer food to tenderize? Or is your sole goal to quickly boil water? The answer to that will help you shop.
data.author: Mike Dannheim
Russell Worley
